title: Buoyant force - two cubes in different fluids

content.question: Cubes <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are made of the same material. Cube <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has edges of length <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> and is fully submerged in a fluid of density <math alttext="0.5 rho" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.5</mn><mi>ρ</mi></math>. Cube <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has edges of length <math alttext="2 L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>L</mi></math> and is fully submerged in a fluid of density <math alttext="rho" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ρ</mi></math>. The buoyant force on Cube <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is <math alttext="F sub B comma 1, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B,1</mtext></msub></math> and the buoyant force on Cube <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is <math alttext="F sub B comma 2, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B,2</mtext></msub></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="F sub B comma 1, end sub, to F sub B comma 2, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B,1</mtext></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B,2</mtext></msub></math> ?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
